div1.p: No 115-G.I. Coquilhatville, October 15, 1907. ANNEX OF LETTER FROM THE GOVERNOR GENERAL FROM 4 9NO SPECIAL

In response to your telegram recalled here, I have the honor to carry to your knowledge that having been informed by Lépoldville of the passage of the Consulate General of the United States, I believe the Government was told of this movement. What is more, while passing the first time, Mr. Smith did not land, expressed regrets in not meeting the Commissioner of the absent district, as no incident of any type had risen, I attached no importance of character to this visit worth communication to the Government. Before leaving, Mr. Smith had said that he counts my return during the voyage, we had concluded that he rose in the Maringa-Lopori zone where he had not further penetrated.

It was only October 12, during your jouney home, that I learned that he had been in the Bangala district. This time he had rested in Coquilhatville about one and a half hours. He was informed of the rising performances in the district. The roles of the performances had no condfidential character, I believed the necessity in giving him the details asked for.

Consul General told me, by informing of the truthfulness of the complaint, that the Lulonga natives had signaled to him the exaggeration of the performance in l'exagération des prestations en poisson required of them. Yet, the natives were not commanded that for 900 grams of smoked fish a month. They had confirmed that the imposition was weekly. I denied this simply by reporting to the sheets of
Mr. Smith had not dreamed of examining the dates of payment. This complaint cannot be made from missionary Gilchrist of Lulonga's instigation.

Incidently, in the course of the very cordial conversation between us, he informed me that in the vicinity of Upoto, I believe, he had himself been doing rubber harvests. My impression is that he finds exaggerated quantity of 3 kilos demanded every month from taxpayers.
Mr. Smit, accompanied by Vice Consul, traveling aboard the "Henry Reed" from the A.B.M.U."
I see nothing else to signal regarding the passage of these diplomatic agents.
